column2: As your father Pepin died, he divided the Empire of the Franks and left one half to you and the other half to your brother. He divided the lands in such a way as to force you to cooperate - but it does not appear to have had the desired effect. The friction is constant, and at every turn it seems your brother is now trying to thwart your plans and weaken your position. You still rule as joint kings, but surely this peace cannot last...

column2: With the death of your brother [From.GetFirstName], the prestige and honor of the Frankish kingship falls on you. He was your rival but now he is no more. There is still much to be done, but here begins a new chapter in the story of [Root.GetFirstName], [Root.GetTitle] of the Franks.

column2: My Lord, the power of your enemies are growing steadily, and while your vassals are surely loyal beyond doubt, it would perhaps be prudent to look for alliances outside the Frankish realm. If you would marry a daughter of the Lombard King, you could gain a powerful ally if things threaten to get out of hand due your brother's devious machinations.

column2: My Lord, there is a lot of grumbling among the lords of the realm. While it is understood that your marriage to [Root.Spouse.GetFirstName] has great political utility, it is hard for many to accept that you have married a princess from the realm of our age-old enemies the Lombards. It has reached the point where you may even be losing the support of some nobles. But perhaps it is still not too late to rectify the situation...

I know my support for your brother in your struggle may have caused you grief. After his death, I have seen how wrong I was to take sides. Please, can you find it in your heart to forgive me and take me into your household, so that I may now repay the injury that I have done to you with new love and loyalty?'

column2:
My son,
I write to you to ask that you stop causing trouble for your brother and do not interefere with his plans. He loves you and you should support him instead of making things difficult for him. [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] sees all and family should not fight with family.

Your loving mother,
[Root.Mother.GetFirstName]

column2: Your mother has come to see you. She speaks to you of your brother and the rivalry between you: 'My dear Charles, it grieves me so that your brother Carloman will not support you as he should but rather has wicked designs on your domains. Rest assured, however, that I shall do all in my power to help and support you. I have even written to him, asking him to cease his plotting and acknowledge that, though the realm is divided between you, he recognize you as the primary ruler of the Franks. I fear, however, that he will not listen to me.

column2: Your son Pepin is illegitimate, but perhaps he could grow into a man worthy of ruling the Franks? His body is twisted and he looks frail, but a boy that overcomes such unfair punishments in life could perhaps with time become an even stronger ruler?

column2: A young nobleman called Roland has approached you, declaring that he wishes to serve you. You have heard his name before, he is known to be a strong warrior and able diplomat, wise beyond his years and especially familiar with the Breton lands to the west. He would surely be a useful addition to your court.

column2: You have been spending a lot of time talking to [roland.GetFullName] recently. He is not only loyal but also wise, amiable and very good company. You find you have many things in common.

column2: Your loyal knight Roland is truly distinguishing himself on campaign. He never fears to lead from the front in battle, he fires up his soldiers with his personal bravery, and he is always first into the fray and the last to withdraw. Where outriders are needed for dangerous scouting missions he insists on going, often being away for days behind enemy lines. If only all your soldiers were this brave and dedicated.

Penetrating deep through the enemy formations and causing havoc, they caused much damage. Then no one knows what happened - maybe they went too far, or maybe they were surprised by an unexpected counterattack. None of them returned...

It is said that they fought fiercely and valiantly. However, none of them returned...

He says he comes from the land of the Danes and has travelled far to offer his services to you, naming you rightful lord of all Christians. He also claims to have seen in a dream how you will conquer all and your name will rise in glory to the Heavens.

column2: The heathen Saxons living North of the realms of the Franks have for a long time held their own against all foreign conquerors, while defiantly staying true to their old religion and raiding Christian lands with no fear of God. No longer shall it be so - the time has come to bring them both the Sword and the Cross. Mercy is something they will find in the next life, should they accept baptism before they perish.

Îíè ñîâåðøàëè íàáåãè íà õðèñòèàíñêèå çåìëè, íå áîÿñü Áîãà. Áîëüøå òàê íå áóäåò - ïðèøëî âðåìÿ ïðèâåñòè èõ ê Ìå÷ó è Êðåñòó. Åñëè îíè íå ïðèìóò õðèñòèàíñòâî, ñìåðòü áóäåò äëÿ íèõ ìèëîñåðäèåì.

column2: You have captured the great pagan sanctuary at Paderborn, one of the holiest places of Germanic paganism. Here stands the great holy tree of Irminsul, which is said to have an immense importance in the heathen faith of the Saxons. To them, Irminsul represents the 'world tree' and is a focus from which they appear to draw much moral strength and inspiration.

Çäåñü ñòîèò âåëèêîå äðåâî Èðìèíñóëü, êîòîðîå, êàê ãîâîðÿò, èìååò îãðîìíîå çíà÷åíèå â ÿçû÷åñêîé âåðå ñàêñîâ. column2: As the bitter war in Saxony rages on, the armies of [From.GetTitledName] have captured Paderborn, the site of the great shrine of the holy tree of Irminsul. By order of the conquering [From.GetTitle], the troops burned the holy tree and then proceeded to destroy the entire shrine. This has infuriated people of the Germanic religion everywhere.

column2: During the course of the Saxon War, you have captured a lot of Saxon prisoners. Many of them are of noble birth and also very defiant in their views and attitude to our righteous Christian conquest. They keep to their heathen ways and scorn the name of Christ. Perhaps it is time to teach these stubborn Saxons a lesson through a show of strength. If we should try, condemn and execute these captured heathen leaders, we may strengthen our cause, please God and put fear into the hearts of our enemies.
column13: Â õîäå Ñàêñîíñêîé âîéíû, Âû çàõâàòèëè ìíîãî ïëåííûõ. Ìíîãèå èç íèõ áëàãîðîäíîãî ïðîèñõîæäåíèÿ è àãðåññèâíî îòíîñÿòñÿ ê íàøåé ïðàâåäíîé õðèñòèàíñêîé ðåëèãèè. Îíè âåðíû ÿçû÷åñêîé âåðå è ïðåçèðàþò èìÿ Õðèñòà. Âîçìîæíî, ïðèøëî âðåìÿ ïðåïîäàòü èì óðîê - íàêàçàíèå ëèäåðîâ óêðåïèò íàøå äåëî. È, äàé Áîã, âñåëèò ñòðàõ â ñåðäöà íàøèõ âðàãîâ.

column2: The Saxons are a people that clings fiercely to its old traditions. After suffering defeats and conquest in spite of tenacious resistance, discontent has continued to simmer in the Pagan Saxon lands. Raids on tax collectors, defiance of church duties, all these things have been annoyances to the new rulers without really presenting any severe danger. Now, however, things seem to have changed. A rebel leader has emerged, uniting the rebellious Saxons and gathering warriors for more concerted attacks. He calls himself Widukind, a name that means 'Child of the Woods', in obvious reference to old Pagan myths and fitting to the hit-and-run tactics used by his forces thus far. The army he is gathering is growing, however...

column2: My Lord, your old enemy Widukind of the Saxons has sent word. He says he recognizes not only the strength of your arms but also the superiority of the Christian faith. He must not come in the way of you fulfilling your destiny as ruler of all the Franks, but I fear a bloody war. Trust me, it will be better like this.'\n\nYou look thoughtfully at your mother, trying to read her mind. There is an odd look of determination in her eyes.

True heir to his father Pepin, descendant of Karl the Hammer, leader of men and master of war, he was claiming his exalted place in history.
